message: Dear President-elect Trump, come visit Wyoming. We have a lot to show you.

Obamacare is on the brink of collapse. Insurance markets are failing. Premiums are soaring. Choice of health plans is dwindling. As chairman of the budget committee, I am playing a key role in passing a resolution that will provide for the repeal of Obamacare while setting the stage for a transition in which those with insurance will not lose access to health care coverage. Our goal is to create a health care system where Washington makes fewer health care decisions, and families are empowered to control their own health care with more choices and lower costs. http://bit.ly/2hRJDT1

For once the EPA made the right decision by not finalizing a rule that would have added unnecessary regulations on uranium mining in Wyoming. I am hopeful that President-elect Trump’s new administration will review the proposed rule carefully to understand the consequences of new red-tape on this vital industry.

Every year, Wyoming students demonstrate their patriotism and willingness to serve their country by applying to our service academies. Apart from a quality education, the service academies open doors and provide a unique set of experiences that graduates will carry with them throughout their careers. It’s an honor to nominate these Wyoming students.

Each week I am sharing a new place to visit in one of Wyoming’s 23 counties. Today I would like to recognize the Anna Miller Museum in Weston County. Relive the American West by visiting the schoolhouse, Jenney Stockade Cabin & homesteader’s house. http://westoncountywyo-museum.org/

I recently asked President-elect Donald Trump’s pick to head the Department of Homeland Security, retired four-star Marine Corps General John Kelly, how he would go about improving security along the U.S. borders and how he might improve morale among Border Patrol personnel in his confirmation hearing. Check out this video to see his response.

This morning the Senate passed a resolution that will set the stage for the repeal of Obamacare that Americans have long demanded while ensuring a stable transition in which those with insurance will not lose access to health care coverage. Learn more here: http://bit.ly/2inXsw6

This report by the BLM is just another politically concocted attempt by the outgoing Administration to demonize coal. Wyomingites know the value of coal and the benefits that taxpayers and energy consumers across America receive from coal production. I am optimistic that President-elect Trump’s Administration will have a better understanding of the essential jobs, tax revenue and energy production that coal provides for our nation.

My friend Senator Lamar Alexander of Tennessee is chairman of the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee. That committee will be one of the leads in working on replacing Obamacare. As Senator Alexander said, the Obamacare bridge is collapsing and we are sending in a rescue team and we will build new bridges to better healthcare.

Obamacare is not sustainable, the health care system is at a dangerous tipping point. But we aren’t stuck with what we have. Read my column in the Casper Star Tribune to find out why we are on the path to repeal Obamacare and how the new Congress plans to help more Americans access a better, lower cost health care system.

The people who are closest to the areas where wolves are being delisted have the best understanding of how to manage them and should be left to do so. Senator John Barrasso and I joined Senator Ron Johnson, Senator Tammy Baldwin and Senator Amy Klobuchar in introducing bipartisan legislation that would delist the gray wolf in Wyoming and other states. I trust local wildlife managers to manage wildlife better than judges, lawyers and the self-serving administrators and lobbyists of environmental groups in Washington miles away.

The inauguration of a new President and the Administration that takes office with him represents a new beginning – a fresh start. There will be new ideas brought to our deliberations in the Congress and new and different proposals and approaches to our future as a nation. As you watched the ceremony, I am sure that you had a great many thoughts about your children and, for many of us, our grandchildren. They are all looking to us to ensure that we do everything we can to protect their future and ensure they will have things better than we did. It is a responsibility we all take very seriously and that will be our goal in the years to come.

It is always best to lead by example, which is what President Trump and Vice President Pence did with their transition team, which gave 20 percent of the funds allocated to them back to the U.S. Treasury. This is something that I have also done in years past with my office and I am glad they used the same approach. Working together, we will put our country on a better path.

Earlier today President Trump signed executive orders aimed at advancing the Keystone XL and Dakota Access pipelines. It is refreshing to see an administration that is committed to energy production and job creation. These types of infrastructure projects can provide a great benefit to our country and I look forward to working with President Trump to support American energy production across the country.

I introduced legislation with Senator John Barrasso and Rep. Liz Cheney to approve an expansion of the Fontenelle Reservoir to ensure Wyoming can finally take advantage of the project’s full potential. Access to a good source of water in Wyoming doesn’t always come easy, but it’s vital to our livelihood.

I am pleased that President Trump has nominated a fiscal conservative for this key post, the White House Office of Management and Budget. South Carolina Rep. Mick Mulvaney has been a vigilant budget hawk during his six years in Congress, including during his time on the House Budget and Oversight Committees. You can see excerpts from the hearing below. Learn more here: http://bit.ly/2j29InS

I joined Senator John Thune in re-introducing a bill to repeal the estate tax, better known as the death tax. Family assets, sometimes built up over generations, should be left in the hands of the family and will be put to better use there in the local community than shipped off to wasteful Washington.

Earlier today President Trump took action to roll back red tape by mandating that for every new regulation issued by a federal agency, at least two previous regulations must be eliminated. Washington has more red tape than they know what to do with and I hope that this new order will force the federal government to take a good look at outdated and overly burdensome regulations.

It is wonderful to hear that the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs has purchased land in Cheyenne to construct Wyoming’s first VA National Cemetery. It will serve 22,000 veterans and their eligible family members to properly honor their courage and sacrifice for this country.

I joined Senator John Barrasso in introducing a resolution of disapproval to overturn the final methane rule from the BLM. It is unnecessary, duplicative and destructive. It is not only harming this country by disrupting America’s energy production, but it’s hurting those folks whose livelihood is based on this industry.

Wyoming should be able to have the flexibility to implement policies that work for our state. I voted to advance Betsy DeVos’s nomination as Secretary of Education to the full Senate because I believe she will allow states and local public school districts to implement their own plans to improve the educational outcomes for all of our students without burdensome federal intrusion. Mrs. DeVos will not be running our schools, that’s the job of Wyomingites. What I heard directly from Mrs. DeVos and what I see in her record, is someone who seeks more educational opportunities for our children. The U.S. Department of Education should not try to exert top-down control of education from Washington as it has done for the better part of the last decade. It should follow the bipartisan Every Students Succeeds Act. Mrs. DeVos assured me she will follow the law and provide states with the flexibility that they have not had in a long time. If she does, parents and teachers will find themselves more in the education driver’s seat than they have been for years.

The Second Amendment is among our most treasured Constitutional rights. This Social Security Administration rule could unconstitutionally deny certain beneficiaries their Second Amendment rights without due process. That’s unacceptable. I cosponsored this resolution to ensure American citizens their Constitutional rights, no matter their age or if they need help managing their finances.

Judge Neil Gorsuch is an admirable choice to be America’s next addition to the Supreme Court. His many years of dedication to the law and service to America’s judicial system clearly qualify him to serve on America’s highest court. His work itself speaks highly of his understanding of the Constitution and the values that we as Americans hold dear. I have met Judge Gorsuch and he has a lot of support from the legal community in Wyoming. As a westerner, he has a good understanding of the issues that matter to our state. He would be a qualified choice under any president.

Automatic spending programs threaten to bankrupt the country. The Social Security Trust Fund won’t be sufficient to cover benefits in two years, which will result in a $1.6 trillion deficit by 2027.  Medicare will be in the red in three years. Learn more here: http://bit.ly/2kSeP7s

Congress passed its first resolution that would overturn an Obama Administration regulation that was aimed at limiting coal production. The ‘stream protection rule’ is clearly aimed more at stopping coal production than protecting the environment. The Obama Administration took many hasty steps to cement its legacy and the Senate should reverse these regulations which shouldn’t have ever been approved.

I applaud President Trump for taking action to reevaluate the implementation of an Obama Administration rule that would limit access to retirement planning for middle-income American families. If we want to ensure that Americans can properly plan for their retirement, we shouldn’t be putting hurdles in their way.

I introduced legislation with Senators John Barrasso and Orrin Hatch that would ensure that Wyoming and other states who are already adequately regulating hydraulic fracturing are protected from redundant regulations from Washington. States who are listening to the concerns of local stakeholders and communities shouldn’t see their efforts superseded by some Washington power grab.

Are you a small business owner interested in growing your business and discovering new tools to help it succeed? Check out the 2017 GRO-Biz Conference and Idea Expo in Casper on February 22 and 23. This is Wyoming’s go-to annual event to learn how government contracting may be the answer for expanding your business.

Today the Senate confirmed U.S. Senator Jeff Sessions to be the next U.S. attorney general. Sessions is a well-educated attorney, accomplished prosecutor and a skilled legislator. I also believe his character, work ethic and temperament make him well-suited to serve as the chief law enforcement officer of the federal government. He has been my friend and colleague for over 20 years and I am proud to support him.

Today the Senate confirmed Rep. Tom Price to be the next Health and Human Services secretary. Dr. Price is an ideal candidate for the job. I am pleased to support a friend and someone I’m honored to have worked with for many years. Not only does he know the health care system as a physician, he knows it as a policymaker who has been a thought leader in health care here in Congress.

As we continue to share a new place to visit in each of Wyoming’s 23 counties, it’s time to recognize Fort Laramie National Historic Site in Goshen County. Come see the largest military outpost of the 1880s! Fort Laramie was a crossroads for American growth and played a key part in the history of the American West. More at: https://www.nps.gov/fola/index.htm

A lot of folks in Wyoming like the change in direction the new Administration is taking, but I understand that a lot of you don’t. Despite some Senate-wide communications difficulties, which should hopefully be behind us, I hear you. I value input from you and appreciate your position even if it is contrary to my own. I hope you can appreciate mine even if you think I’m wrong. I believe we all want what is best for Wyoming. Here’s a video with a little more about what has been happening since the first of the year in the Senate and my take on some of the issues.

Earlier today I met with Judge Gorsuch. He has a lot of support from folks in Wyoming from both parties and I believe he has a good understanding of the legal issues that matter to people in my home state. His work itself speaks highly of his understanding of the Constitution and the values that we as Americans hold dear. Gorsuch is an admirable choice to be America’s next Supreme Court justice. Learn more here: http://bit.ly/2ldfWkP
NA

My staff will be at the UW Career and Internship Fair on Tuesday, February 21 at the Rochelle Gateway Center to talk about my internship program that takes place in D.C. An internship provides the unique opportunity to participate directly in the legislative process and witness democracy first-hand. Interns gain valuable experience on Capitol Hill by working on a variety of policy areas from healthcare to finance to energy and much more. Stop on by to learn more!

If you would like to let me know about an issue you’re having with the federal government, and you don’t want to call or send a letter, and want to talk to a person face to face, you’re in luck. My state staff will be holding office hours in Buffalo on February 15. Stop by and share your thoughts.

If you are a junior in high school and are looking for a truly unique experience I recommend applying as a page to the U.S. Senate for the summer sessions. The page program allows students to have a front row seat during debates in the Senate. Check out the link below to learn more about this great opportunity and how to apply.

Today the Senate passed a resolution of disapproval to protect Social Security beneficiaries from losing their Second Amendment rights without due process. It is now on its way to the president who is expected to sign the legislation.
Today I met with Susan Fessler from Lander who competes in Special Olympics. These athletes compete in a wide variety of winter and summer sports.

Today the Senate confirmed Rep. Mick Mulvaney, R-S.C., as the next director of the White House Office of Management and Budget. This position is crucial to helping the federal government function in what is shaping up to be a very challenging budget environment that requires the attention of every one of us. Learn more here: http://bit.ly/2kNVUdv

For too long, the Equal Access to Justice Act has been abused by special interest groups in order to push their agendas through the courts. One of the most fundamental problems facing this act is the lack of transparency. I introduced legislation with Senator John Barrasso and Rep. Liz Cheney that would reinstate important reporting requirements in order to track the cost of excessive litigation to the American taxpayer, and make sure the law is working to help the small businesses, seniors, and veterans for whom the law was passed in the first place.

I am sharing a new place to visit in each of Wyoming’s 23 counties. Today we are featuring the Campbell County Rockpile Museum. Located in my home county, the museum focuses on local and regional history with an emphasis on the culture and people of Campbell County. Along with a collection of western artifacts, there are many hands-on activities for both children and adults and some great outdoor exhibits. Learn more: https://www.ccgov.net/317/Rockpile-Museum

Finishing our series exploring places to visit in each Wyoming’s 23 counties, we have the Kendrick Mansion at the Trail End State Historic Site in Sheridan County. The mansion is a fully furnished historic museum that interprets the time period 1913-1933. Take a tour to see the exhibits and displays utilizing primarily original artifacts from the home. Learn more: http://www.trailend.co/

I was saddened to hear that former U.S. Congressman John Wold had left us. He has been a part of Wyoming history - in many businesses, local, state and national politics, and philanthropy, all for a long time. I have gotten to learn from him in each of those endeavors. His distinctive voice always grabbed attention. He was notable in anything he did. He was an example of the importance of family. He was a giving person and good example for us to follow. Diana and I send our deepest sympathies to the Wold family.

I cosponsored a bipartisan resolution designating February as Career and Technical Education Month to encourage learning opportunities so more people have job opportunities in high-skill, high-wage and high-demand fields.

It was great to tour WESTECH in Casper, a designer and builder of mining truck bodies in the state since 1938. Their custom and innovative designs help mining companies across the world maximize their potential. One of their designs set the Guinness World Record for the largest truck body by volume and was built for use at the North Antelope Rochelle Mine north of Douglas.

Governor Matt Mead and I kicked off Gro-Biz in Casper, February 22. It’s a great event where Wyoming businesses can make their sales pitch to federal and state government agencies and a good opportunity to bring more work to Wyoming businesses. There is more information on my webpage- enzi.senate.gov .

If you would like to let me know about an issue you’re having with the federal government, and you don’t want to call or send a letter, and want to talk to a person face to face, you’re in luck. My state staff will be holding office hours in Shoshoni, Riverton and Lander on February 27. Stop by and share your thoughts.
I stopped by the Wyoming Legislature recently and thanked them for all they do for the state, especially in these difficult economic times that call for tough choices.

There are over 45 federal programs that support early learning and child care, but unfortunately many of them are overlapping and fragmented. For years I have worked in a bipartisan fashion to organize these programs in order to get as many resources to states and localities as possible, instead of just supporting federal administrators. I have had some success, but ran into a brick wall with the last Administration. I am hoping Secretaries DeVos and Price share my goal and will help us achieve better results for students and the federal budget.
I recently toured the Cheyenne VA Medical Center where I was able to see firsthand how we provide medical care to our veterans who gave so much to this great country of ours.

Today’s executive order to review the waters of the United States rule is a good first step for people across the country worried about the EPA’s attempt to regulate every creek and pond. This rule was another attempt by the EPA to control our water and by extension state sovereignty, property rights, communities and individuals. For the sake of farmers, ranchers, manufacturers and small businesses it is time to end this outrageous regulation.

Today I heard the president deliver a message about the things we as a nation can achieve. Too often in the heat of political battle, we lose track of the bigger picture and the commonalities that bind us. That could mean safety for our families and communities; good jobs to support our loved ones; or the opportunity to make the most of our lives. As Americans, we not only share many of the same goals and desires, we share the responsibility inherent in our democratic system of government to work together to ensure those dreams are within reach.  The president’s speech wasn’t just about what we hope for, it was also about taking action. He laid out an agenda aimed at addressing real problems for real people. The president has a large spotlight which he can shine on the major problems that need to be fixed, but Congress tackles the details of how to fix them. We need to stay true to our values and beliefs and remember that no person, or party, has all the answers. Governing is the art of coming together to find solutions and common ground. I look forward to working with my colleagues and the president to craft those solutions in order to ensure our country is on the path to a better future.

The Senate confirmed Representative Ryan Zinke, R- Mont., to be the next secretary of the Interior. Being from a western state, Zinke understands the incredible importance of public land issues to states like Wyoming. With so much of our land managed by the federal government, it is key that they are open for multiple uses such as recreation, agriculture and energy production. I look forward to working with him on the critical issues that matter to Wyoming and other western states.

I recently sent a letter urging President Trump to end the moratorium on new federal coal leasing that was wrongly initiated by the Obama Administration. The halt to coal leasing jeopardized tens of thousands of jobs directly and indirectly to the coal industry and hurt states and tribes that rely on coal royalties to support critical education, transportation and infrastructure programs.

Last week I ran into the Career Technical Education State Director, Guy Jackson, in line at the grocery store and ended up with an impromptu visit of the Wyoming Department of Education. Great to have a chance to catch up with Superintendent Jillian Balow, Dicky Shanor, Kari Eakins, Brent Bacon and Randall Butt.

A federal appeals court today upheld a U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service decision to remove the gray wolf in Wyoming from the endangered species list. This ruling is a win for Wyoming and all those who have worked so hard to return management of the gray wolf to the state. The state of Wyoming has been working on this issue with local stakeholders and the federal government for years and the courts should have never blocked the delisting in the first place.

The Senate today voted to overturn the BLM’s Planning 2.0 Rule, which implemented sweeping changes to how the BLM develops resource management plans. Overturning this rule would return power back to those who actually live near BLM lands in western states. We should be empowering state and local voices in land management processes, not trying to sideline them. The resolution now goes to the president’s desk, who is expected to sign it into law.
NA

The Senate voted today to rescind a Department of Education regulation that directly contradicted a bipartisan education bill Congress passed in 2015, which put control back in the hands of states and parents. The Education Department regulation would allow the federal government to mandate, direct and control state and local school accountability systems. I am glad that Congress took action to stop this regulation in its tracks, because it is states, not the federal government, that should be in charge of school accountability.

This is an outstanding endorsement for Supreme Court Nominee Neil Gorsuch from a very diverse group of people who have known him well for many years. “We are Democrats, Republicans, Libertarians and independents; progressives, conservatives and moderates; religious and non-observant; married, single and divorced; men and women; straight and gay…” I’ve met him on several occasions and also believe him to be an admirable choice. When the Senate begins his consideration, I hope that those who have opposed the new president can admit he got this one right.

If you don’t want to call or send a letter, but want to talk with a person face to face, my staff is available. I’ll be in DC for votes and committee work, but  my staff will listen and pass on to me any comments you have about any issue. They will be holding office hours in Moorcroft, Pine Haven and Sundance on March 14. Come on by.

On March 12, 1912 Juliette Gordon began the Girl Scouts of America with a troop of just 18 girls. Today, the program has 2 million active members and 59 million alumni. The Girl Scouts help young women become the leaders of the future. In fact, 76 percent of my female coworkers in the Senate are former Girl Scouts! This is a great program that opens doors for young women in every state, and National Girl Scout Week lets us celebrate their success.
For a short while this Congress I was 17th in seniority (now 16th) in the Senate, which is the same number Wyoming puts on license plates for Campbell county, my home.

The biggest bank you’ve never heard of is lending out a trillion dollars of taxpayer money while regularly ignoring government regulations and using questionable accounting practices. It’s time we get a look at their books, before it is too late.

On March 25 at Cody High School and on April 8 at Natrona County High School, representatives from America’s prestigious military academies will be meeting with Wyoming students and families to talk about the opportunities an academy has to offer, and the many benefits that one can gain from military service. I have the greatest respect for our servicemen and women, and highly encourage anyone interested to come and learn more about the great future a degree from a service academy can provide.

Congrats to the Wyoming Academic Bowl Team of Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing high school students! They finished second in the West Regionals Academic Bowl and for the third consecutive year advanced to the National Academic Bowl, which is scheduled to be held in Washington, D.C. in April.

I sponsored a resolution declaring March as National Colorectal Cancer Awareness Month to help the fight against the second deadliest form of cancer in America. Regular screenings can help catch the growth early when it is most treatable. As a husband of a colorectal cancer survivor, I know firsthand just how important early treatment is. Everyone deserves a fighting chance against this disease, and regular screenings are the first step to survival.

If you don’t want to call or send a letter, my staff will be available to talk to in person. I’ll be in DC for votes and committee work, but  my staff will listen and pass on to me any comments you have about any issue. They will be holding office hours in Star Valley Ranch on March 23. Come on by.
Last week I was able to learn more about The Range 307, Pronghorn Center & Inspiration Hall, Westwood Engraving class and Rawhide Elementary School all in my hometown of Gillette.

This week the Senate Judiciary Committee is holding hearings on the nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch. I believe the U.S. Supreme Court needs a judge like Gorsuch who understands the West. Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley said a committee vote is expected April 3.

The Wind River Job Corps Center in Riverton is focusing on energy industry training so their job placement is tremendous. I spoke about this and equal pay during the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee hearing on Alex Acosta’s nomination to be the next labor secretary. Learn more here: http://bit.ly/2mwLuns

After years of delays, this approval of a construction permit for the expansion of the Keystone XL pipeline is a sign that our country is back on the right track. I appreciate that the Trump Administration worked quickly on this issue. America should be focused on encouraging energy development. The construction of the Keystone XL pipeline is not only a job creator, but will play an important role in American energy security and the growth of our economy.

The federal government should be sharing its endangered species data and allowing those most affected by a proposal to review the information. State, local and tribal entities need to have a seat at the table when federal agencies are proposing regulations that could have significant ramifications. We should encourage an open process that relies on the best data available. I introduced legislation that would give the opportunity to verify, dispute, or complement the information federal agencies use in listings species.

Today President Trump issued an executive order to review the Clean Power Plan and the moratorium on federal coal leasing. This decision is great for Wyoming and all those who rely on affordable energy. I have opposed the Clean Power Plan and coal leasing moratorium from the very start, and I am pleased to see the president’s actions.

Across the country, fraternities and sororities looking to use donations to help construct new buildings or make safety improvements are finding themselves blocked by a major road block, the U.S. tax code. While colleges and universities are able to use charitable deductions to build and maintain student housing, other not-for-profit student housing groups are not allowed to do the same. I introduced legislation with Senator Ben Cardin this week to make the tax system fairer by ending that arbitrary distinction.

Borrowers of federal student loans need transparent information when considering loan options and federal student loans should have to be upfront about their true costs. I introduced legislation that would provide more transparency so families can be better informed about their financing options.

If you don’t want to call or send a letter, my staff will be available to talk to in person. I’ll be in DC for votes and committee work, but my staff will listen and pass on to me any comments you have about any issue. They will be holding office hours in Glenrock, Douglas and Lusk on March 30, and in Newcastle and Upton on March 31. Come on by.

Change can be hard sometimes, but switching to a dollar coin could save our country $150 million a year. I introduced legislation with Senator John McCain that would modernize our currency by moving to a $1 dollar coin, reduce the cost of nickel production and suspend the minting of the penny, which currently costs more than one cent to produce. Our country is in a difficult financial position because we didn’t value the cost of the dollars we spent. We can’t afford to keep that up, and these innovative opportunities are a way to save taxpayer money that is really just being wasted with each new dollar we print and penny we mint.

All across the country, faith-based charities and organizations are working hard to find children safe, loving and permanent homes. This is wonderful work, and we should be looking to encourage these organizations, not limiting their efforts because of their religious beliefs. I introduced legislation today to ensure faith-based institutions and individuals can continue to provide services for those who need them.

If you don’t want to call or send a letter, my staff will be available to talk to in person. I’ll be in DC for votes and committee work, but my staff will listen and pass on to me any comments you have about any issue. They will be holding office hours in Wright and Gillette on April 6. Come on by.

I spoke to President Donald Trump’s pick to head the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), Scott Gottlieb, MD, today about aligning drug approval with advances in science, access to drugs, as well as needed improvements in the biosimilar drug approval process.

I am confident that Neil Gorsuch is qualified to be a member of the Supreme Court because of his steadfast commitment to the rule of law. His opinions reflect his respect for following the law as it is written, and applying and adhering to judicial precedent.  He is a judge who applies the law to the facts of a case and reaches the conclusion that examination yields, regardless of his own personal beliefs. Learn more here: http://bit.ly/2nYXRGh
Before his meeting with Chinese President Xi, we asked President Trump to focus on human rights, security, trade and other issues important to us.

When you find a place where interests meet, the cooperation can result in positive procedural changes. Ranking Member Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., and I and all the members of the Senate Budget Committee were able to do that recently. We have made considering a budget more orderly, meaningful and transparent.

I congratulate Judge Neil Gorsuch on his confirmation to the highest court in the land. He is an admirable choice to serve in this prestigious capacity and I have faith that he will execute his responsibilities with the utmost skill and honor. He has a keen understanding of the rule of law, and as a westerner, will provide a unique perspective to key issues. I believe he will serve the American people well.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau should not use the IRS as a conduit to solicit Americans’ stories about money. I joined other senators in sending a letter to the Treasury to stop including flyers from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau with official IRS mailings.

Many people have been negatively impacted in Wyoming by coal industry layoffs, especially in northeast Wyoming.  Governor Mead and the Wyoming Department of Workforce Services have announced the availability of some retraining resources.  https://lnks.gd/2/3VmmwH

It was great to be in Evanston. Nice to talk with the Economic Development Council and attend an Evanston Small Business Network meeting. Also thanks to the city council and Director of Administrative Services Amy Grenfell for giving me a tour of the Evanston Rail Yard Complex. The work they are doing to fix up the old Roundhouse that used to house Union Pacific trains is quite amazing.

There is no better reminder about how great Wyoming students are than having a chance to talk with them directly. Thanks to Evanston’s Middle School and High School for the opportunity to share some of my stories, for the great questions that students asked and for the tours of the schools by the student councils.

Enjoyed the tour of the new Aspen Mountain Medical Center in Rock Springs, and thanks to the staff for showing me around the beautiful facility. Also was able to tour the J.R. Simplot plant, where they are building a new ammonia facility to provide continued investment in the community. Fact of the Day: J.R. Simplot developed the first frozen French fries and made a handshake deal with McDonald founder Ray Kroc to sell them their first frozen fries, which they still provide today.

It was great to tour the Sinclair refinery and learn not only about how they produce propane, gasoline, jet fuel, diesel and road asphalt, but their work over the last few years to become a world class leader in safety.

AMAZING Wyoming photos!!!  Last year I asked people if they would submit photos from around Wyoming that could be used to update my website (enzi.senate.gov). We were able to use some on my redesigned webpage, but we got dozens of amazing entries. Here are just a few pictures that truly show the wonderful talent that Wyoming folks have. They have captured the natural beauty of the Cowboy state along with the culture and spirit. Thanks so much for all those who contributed. Feel free to like the photos you think are the best.

Enjoyed touring the National Weather Service Forecast Office in Riverton. It was great to see that they not only work hard to provide an accurate weather forecast, but are involved in communities across the state in order to provide awareness, training and to ensure they are gathering the best information from weather watchers in Wyoming. Thanks to Tim Troutman, Chris Jones, and all those at the National Weather Service Forecast Office in Riverton for all the work you do to help keep Wyoming safe and informed.

The Wind River Job Corps Center in Riverton is doing a spectacular job helping kids across Wyoming and the West get the training and education that can take them far. It was great to see the range of great programs they provide and also talk with the teachers and students on campus. It is clear the Job Corps Center is making a real difference. The center has only been in operation for two years, but already is ranked number one in the country for job placement. It is amazing to see how far it has come after so many years of working to help get the project off the ground.

Got to see the new “Thinking Money” exhibit at the Laramie County Library earlier this week. It strives to teach kids, teens and their parents and educators about financial literacy topics—like saving, spending and avoiding fraud—in a way that is not only understandable, but fun. Motivating visitors to learn more about how money works and how their money decisions are determined is good for the financial security of our citizens.

I know that from the outside, almost every business looks easy to operate. But once you learn more about them, you realize how much work they take and all the challenges they have to overcome. That is why when I travel around the state, I make sure to get into a few Wyoming businesses to see what they do and how they do it. Brewista in Cheyenne not only designs and manufactures some of the best brewing equipment for baristas around the world, but they have also designed an innovative machine that makes homemade fresh nut milk, such as almond milk. Just add nuts and water, and in minutes you are done. I also went to the Cheyenne Refinery earlier this week to learn more about what they are doing to help provide gasoline, diesel, and other products to the rocky mountain area. The refinery has been around since World War II and has made massive improvements to stay up to date

Researchers at the University of Wyoming now have access to the one of a kind High Bay Research Facility, which provides state of the art equipment to understand how to maximize unconventional oil and gas recovery. The unique capabilities of the building are truly amazing. #UWYO

The University of Wyoming has done some amazing work on their athletic facilities in order to create a supportive environment for student athletes, and they still have some big plans for the future. Thanks to Wyoming Cowgirls Basketball Coach Joe Legerski, Football Coach Craig Bohl, and Senior Associate Athletics Director Randy Welniak for all the information about their work. Also was great to be able to talk with a few of the Cowboy Basketball players.

In Laramie earlier this week, I got to hear about the important issues facing the Laramie Airport and was able to see the new Laramie High School. The building is quite impressive and will hopefully provide some great resources for the students to help them succeed.

Enjoyed being in the Powell/Cody region this week. Got to talk with agriculture partners from the area, and toured the manufacturing company Wyoming Completion Technologies, Inc, which designs and manufactures high quality oil tools. Amazing to see their high tech robotic arm at work, nicknamed "Minion".

When you are in need of medical attention, you want the service fast no matter where you are. That is where medical air service plays a key role. Got to visit REACH Medical Air Service in Cody and take a ride in their medical helicopter to see how they perform rescue services.

Thanks to Mary Turney who wrote me about the Casting for Recovery program in Wyoming. The program is designed to “enhance the quality of life of women with breast cancer through a unique retreat program that combines breast cancer education and peer support with the therapeutic sport of fly fishing,” according to the organization’s website. The Wyoming retreat will be held at the Absaroka Ranch near Dubois in July. (It’s a beautiful place and I commend Budd and Emi Betts for hosting this program.)  Any woman who resides in Wyoming and has received a breast cancer diagnosis is eligible to apply for one of the 14 spots available. The application deadline is May 12.
Even though Wyoming has an exemption, I appreciate the Trump Administration’s willingness to take a look at the National Antiquities Act. Some presidents have abused it.

I applaud President Trump for signing an executive order today that requires a study to see where the federal government has unlawfully overstepped in trying to control our children’s education. It is important that we help return authority of our kid's education to where it belongs, with our teachers, parents and those at the local and state level. Congress passed a new law a few years ago to do just that, and this new order can play a role in helping those efforts.

The Marketplace Fairness Act is about supporting jobs and services we have in our towns while ensuring states have the ability to collect taxes they are owed, if they choose to. Right now, thousands of local brick-and-mortar businesses are forced to do business at a competitive disadvantage because they have to collect sales and use taxes while remote sellers do not. This legislation promotes internet fairness by putting Main Street businesses on a level playing field with online retailers. In 2013, the Senate passed this bill with bipartisan support. It’s time to give states the right to enforce their own laws without having to get permission from Washington.

The U.S. Court of Appeals decided today to delay a ruling regarding the clean power plan lawsuit. By granting the Trump Administration’s request to suspend the lawsuit for 60 days, the court has provided the Environmental Protection Agency with time to review and rescind the program. This is a real victory for Wyoming and for all those who rely on affordable energy. The Clean Power Plan was designed to shut down coal power plants. Hopefully this court decision will instead signal the end of this terrible Obama-era regulation.

If you don’t want to call or send a letter, my staff will be holding office hours in Laramie on May 2. I’ll be in DC for votes and committee work, but my staff will be there to listen and pass along to me any comments you have about any issue. Come on by.

It is critical for Congress and the federal government to focus on policies that actually promote private sector growth. I held a Senate Budget Committee hearing on this issue earlier today. We cannot spend our way out of our fiscal challenges. Instead we must look to the private sector to create long-term growth, and often the policies needed to encourage business investment are as simple as getting out of the way.  Regulatory relief, tax reform and simplification, and reducing uncertainty in government policies can promote business investment and private sector growth. More info here: http://bit.ly/2pxXN2R

Today Congress passed a bipartisan spending bill that provides billions in additional funding for our military, the largest border security increase in a decade and support for programs on which communities and families throughout Wyoming rely. All of this was done while staying within the spending limits Congress set. It is virtually impossible to write legislation that makes everyone happy, but I believe this bill does a good job at threading the needle. Click the link below for more details.
Join me in celebrating Teacher Appreciation Day. There are more than 7,000 teachers in Wyoming. If you see one today, remember to thank them for everything they do for our students.

I introduced bipartisan legislation with Senator Ron Wyden to protect responsible knife owners. With conflicting knife laws across the country, it can be difficult for individuals to know if they are violating the law when they are travelling with a knife. This bill would help fix that by ensuring that if you’re traveling from point A to point C with a knife that is legal in both locations, you shouldn’t have to worry about being charged with a knife possession crime in between at point B.

“I think we need to be bold in getting the economy going.” Those were the words of former Senator Phil Gramm, who spoke to the Senate Budget Committee today about the importance of growing our economy, and how government policies can either help, or hurt, that process. Whether it is tax rates, regulations or government spending, big policy changes can and do alter the economy. But regardless of growth, our spending still exceeds our income, and that will need to be something our nation addresses.

It was an honor to receive the Toy Association’s bipartisan Champion of Play award for dedication to education. Our children deserve to receive the best education our country can provide for them so they can learn what they need to succeed.

Today the National Museum of Wildlife Art in Wyoming is celebrating its 30th anniversary. I am pleased to have helped pass legislative language in 2008 to officially designate it a “national museum.” This is an honor shared by a select group, including the Smithsonian museums. It is a testament to its wonderful collection of art.

I voted in committee today to advance legislation that would allow Congress to review key federal regulations. Congress has given far too much power to unaccountable bureaucrats who implement too many regulations, many that are harmful to our country and our economy. The REINS Act & Midnight Rules Relief Act would give Congress new tools to help review and stop bad regulations in their tracks.

It is important for Congress to ask if we are using taxpayer dollars wisely and operating the government as efficiently and effectively as the managers of a private sector company would. I held a Senate Budget Committee hearing on this issue earlier today. We must identify ways the government can operate in a more cost-effective manner. More info here: http://bit.ly/2rsozrz

My congratulations to the Wyoming Office of Tourism for being a finalist at the OBIE Awards for their ads. Creators were inspired by the question "Why visit Wyoming?" I especially like the fly fishing billboard.

Just like hardworking American families, the government can’t continually spend more than it makes. What happens when we run out of financial gimmicks? It is time for Congress and the president to do what every American family has to do, live within our means. I commend the president on proposing a budget that balances, which has not happened in the last eight years. I also applaud the approach contained in the president’s budget to review and reform government programs and agencies to ensure they are both effective and efficient. But the president’s budget is a suggestion. We will take a close look at his budget, but Congress is mandated by the Constitution with key spending responsibilities and will ultimately decide what the nation’s fiscal priorities will be.

Some people may not like how President Trump balances his budget, but I commend him for trying and I am looking for suggestions. The nation is in the worst fiscal shape since World War II. For more info: http://bit.ly/2rEunSq
I introduced legislation with Rep. Liz Cheney and Senator John Barrasso that would allow states to collect their own federal mineral royalties, protecting money that is rightfully owed to the states.

Over the last 50 years, our strategy of isolating Cuba hasn’t been very successful. I introduced bipartisan legislation with Senator Amy Klobuchar that would lift the travel restriction to Cuba, providing new opportunities for American businesses, farmers and ranchers. Trade is very powerful. It can be more than just the flow of goods, but also the flow of ideas – ideas of freedom and democracy are the keys to positive change in any nation. It is time we moved on from the failed ideas of the past and tried a new approach to Cuba.

On this Memorial Day, as on so many others in the past, we join together to remember those who gave their lives over the years so that our nation might be strong and free.  Because of them, we are able to pursue the American Dream and all that it promises and provides to us and our families.

When I became the mayor of Gillette more than 40 years ago, we began efforts to provide more water for Gillette’s growing population. Yesterday, we celebrated as water flowed through the Madison Pipeline for the first time. This 42-mile pipeline expands Gillette’s groundwater sources to improve system delivery and meet the city’s long-term water needs. All of Gillette’s mayors and city leaders over the years have worked hard to make this possible and I was honored to celebrate this accomplishment with them at a ceremony at the Donkey Creek Pump Station yesterday. Today I spoke at the opening of the Wyoming Association of Municipalities convention in Gillette. This weekend I have more events in different parts of the state. The people I speak with are constant reminders of why our state is so special.

I applaud President Trump for making the decision to withdraw the United States from the Paris climate agreement. The choice by the former Administration to join the agreement without input from Congress was disingenuous and irresponsible. The Constitution requires the Senate to advise and consent to any treaty made by the president. The Paris agreement demanded too much from our country while letting others, such as China and India, off the hook for years. It was a bad deal for America. I look forward to working with the Trump Administration to continue positive policy reforms that support American energy and our economy.

If you want to avoid stress when you travel internationally, here is a tip: renew your passport early. The U.S. Department of State expects to handle more than 20 million passport applications this year. There are more passports expiring than usual, so processing time and turnaround could be longer as the State Department deals with the high volume of renewal requests. My office can help with your passport needs, but the longer you wait the more difficult it becomes. Some foreign countries require travelers’ passports to have at least six months of validity. Renewing a passport by mail can take eight weeks or more. An ounce of prevention…don’t wait to renew your passport.
Today we remember those brave Americans who stormed the beaches 73 years ago in order to fight for our freedom. May we never forget their sacrifices. #DDay73

Today the Senate passed a bipartisan bill that would reform the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs by allowing the secretary to dismiss bad employees and ensure appropriate due process protections for whistleblowers. I cosponsored the legislation, which would help bring needed accountability to the VA to help ensure our veterans receive the care they deserve.

No matter what else happens, any week you get to spend traveling around Wyoming is a good week. I enjoyed speaking at the Wyoming Association of Municipalities Convention in Gillette and attending Wyoming Boys’ State in Douglas. It was also a pleasure to attend the Lions Clubs International District 15 Convention, and receive the Melvin Jones Fellowship honor, in Cheyenne this weekend.

I appreciate the tone being set by Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke, who announced today he is reviewing federal land management plans concerning the sage grouse. The state of Wyoming has developed an effective plan to protect the sage grouse within our borders while also allowing for responsible energy development and other land uses, so I was heartened to hear Secretary Zinke say it was important for the federal government to work closely with the states and for the federal government to be a good neighbor. It’s a delicate balance between conservation, industry, state, local and federal concerns and a heavy-handed approach from Washington could upset that balance.

If you are going to be a junior in high school and looking for a truly unique experience, I recommend applying to be a page to the U.S. Senate for the fall session. The “fiduciary rule” that will make it more difficult for many Americans to plan their retirement is set to take effect today. I cosponsored legislation to instead provide common sense rules to ensure that families can plan for the future affordably while feeling secure in the financial advice they receive. The federal government is placing unnecessary hurdles in the way of hardworking American families trying to plan for their retirement. The misguided fiduciary rule will hurt the exact people it is designed to help, putting average American families at a disadvantage by essentially limiting their access to financial advice. The Senate passed a resolution this week to commemorate the organization’s 100th anniversary. As a Lion, I was pleased to cosponsor this bipartisan resolution, which recognizes Lions Clubs International for a long history of humanitarian service. More here:

After 13 years, China has ended its ban on U.S. beef imports. One of the world’s largest markets is now open for Wyoming beef business. We are proud of our Wyoming ranchers. The opportunity to export our beef to more than a billion people in China could make a real difference for those around the Cowboy state.

In a Senate Budget Committee hearing today, I discussed with U.S. Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin the need for his department to address America’s mammoth national debt and boost economic growth. He also agreed with me that family-owned businesses should not face the threat of financial ruin caused by the death tax. It is time we free Americans from that burden, allowing them to preserve the livelihoods for their families and future generations. More info here: http://bit.ly/2sydGIY

As we celebrate Flag Day today, we celebrate our country’s symbol that stands for liberty and justice. It is a symbol of our values and principles wherever it flies around the world. Every thread represents our belief in freedom and the strength of our citizens. It is a constant reminder of the sacrifices our soldiers have made over the years for those ideals. It embodies the doctrines of our Constitution and the Declaration of Independence, including the belief that we are all endowed with the rights of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

The U.S. Senate passed a bipartisan measure today that would allow expanded sanctions against Iran and Russia. This bill would clamp down on Iran’s missile programs and choke off support of terrorism. The bill would also hold Russia accountable for its aggression in Ukraine and Crimea, along with its cyber-attacks, interference in elections and its continuing aggression in Syria.

If you want to run a successful business, it can help to be innovative. Powerful technology is becoming more accessible to us every day. Ranchers in Wyoming are a perfect example of an industry taking advantage of technological advancements to improve efficiency and marketing. I wrote about it here:
No coal = no Netflix? Renewable energy sources are important and we should develop them, but not at the expense of other resources. We need them all to meet our growing needs.

Senator John Barrasso, Congressman Liz Cheney and I were pleased to present the Congressional Gold Medal to 24 Wyoming students today at the Capitol. (Only California and Florida had more Gold Medalists.) The Congressional Gold Medal is the highest award bestowed by Congress. With 373 recipients across 39 states, this was the largest class in history. I congratulate these young people for their hard work and dedication. Learn more here: http://bit.ly/2sRzUp2

After months of hard work, Senate Republicans are proposing solutions to address the challenges to health care created by Obamacare that are affecting millions of hardworking families. Senate Democratic leaders have repeatedly declared they would not be part of getting rid of the current deficient system. Members of the GOP conference discussed many different options. The plan we’ve released today is focused on tackling the problem of skyrocketing premiums while stabilizing the collapsing Obamacare insurance markets that threaten to leave millions of Americans with no affordable options for health care. The proposal is also focused on fixing the challenges facing Medicaid while retaining our commitment to provide health care to our most vulnerable populations. Most importantly though, it repeals the individual and employer mandates freeing the American people from the requirement that forced families to purchase insurance they either did not want or could not afford. I look forward to working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to help the nation transition from Obamacare’s broken promises to better care.

The Fish and Wildlife Service announced their decision to delist the grizzly bears within Yellowstone today. I am pleased to see the administration recognizing the recovered status of the grizzly bear in the Yellowstone area. It is good to see management returned to state hands where it belongs. This is great news for Wyoming.

President Trump signed a Department of Veterans Affairs accountability bill into law today, which I cosponsored. These needed reforms brings accountability and transparency to VA facilities by holding employees responsible for misconduct and establishing better protections for whistleblowers within the department.

I am pleased that the Trump administration is taking an important step to overturn the Waters of the United States rule. The EPA’s overreaching Waters of the United States rule would allow Washington to regulate nearly every creek and pond. The EPA should not have complete control over one of Wyoming’s most precious resources.
New Senate health care draft would allow for flexibility and continued improvements. Read more from an interview I had this week:

I applaud today’s order by Secretary of the Interior Ryan Zinke to streamline the backlogged permitting process for mineral leases on federal lands. It is important that the federal permitting process for oil, gas and other resources is consistent and reliable if we want to encourage development in Wyoming, but right now the system is obviously not working. What should take 30 days is taking 257 days on average. This new order would not only address the current permitting backlogs, but also identify areas where improvements in the oil and gas leasing program can be made.
Happy birthday to our wonderful state! On this day in 1890, President Benjamin Harrison signed Wyoming’s statehood bill, making it the 44th state.

More options in order to get better care. That is what the Senate is offering with a revised version of the health care draft bill. We shared a draft a few weeks ago for everyone to see. We’ve listened and made revisions. All senators will have a chance to offer further changes in an open amendment process. This is how legislating works. The journey to a better American health care system begins here.

Senate Majority Leader McConnell has delayed the Senate’s August state work district work period so we can continue to work on important issues, but much of the logjam we’ve had to contend with is due to needless and purely political stunts. Minority senators have delayed crucial appointments made by President Trump. This obstruction of nominations should come to an end so we can fill these vacant positions and allow more people to get to work for Wyoming and the nation.

Nearly 19,600 Wyoming residents paid the Obamacare individual mandate penalty in 2014 to tune of $5.3 million. About 7,000 of those residents had annual incomes below $25,000. Our Senate bill would eliminate the individual mandate and give people more, inexpensive insurance choices.

As an Eagle Scout myself, it was great to speak with Wyoming Boy Scouts at the U.S. Capitol yesterday with Senator John Barrasso and Rep. Liz Cheney. I even brought along my Eagle Scout walking stick I received at the 2013 National Scout Jamboree.

No matter how difficult, we shouldn’t give up on improving health care. I went to the Senate floor today to talk about how this isn’t just about politics. This is about real people and whether or not they can afford an insurance premium that is in some cases higher than their rent or their mortgage payment each month. I will keep working, and I am committed to passing the best product that we can deliver to the people of Wyoming and for our country.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is at it again, taking choice away from consumers by issuing a rule that will dictate what they can and can’t do. I cosponsored a resolution to overturn the new regulation. The unaccountable Consumer Financial Protection Bureau should not be in the business of essentially writing new laws, especially one like this that, according to its own 2015 study, could leave consumers worse off. Read more about it below.

Cowboys bring to life the Code of the West. In 2005, U.S. Senator Craig Thomas began the tradition of naming the fourth Saturday of July – which coincides with Cheyenne Frontier Days – the National Day of the American Cowboy. By honoring one of the greatest symbols of Wyoming, we offer a fitting tribute to our agricultural heritage and a lifestyle that endures still in the Cowboy State. Although the path to pass commemorative resolutions is being blocked by the Senate minority leadership, I would still like to recognize July 22 as the National Day of the American Cowboy.

I have said from the beginning that we need to fix America’s health care system in order to help those struggling under the failures of Obamacare. The vote on the motion to proceed today provides us with an opportunity to do just that. Health care is not a simple issue, but no matter how difficult it is, we need to find a way forward. We should continue to strive to improve our health care system.

Today Congress passed legislation to establish new sanctions, and enhance existing sanctions, against Russia, Iran and North Korea. It is important that our nation can hold bad actors around the world accountable for their behavior.

I am disappointed that we were unable to make more progress to fix our health care system at this point in time, but this is not the end of the line. The people suffering under the failures of Obamacare still need relief from the disastrous law. We all know health care is complicated, but that doesn’t change the need for us to find a way forward in order to provide relief for our constituents. And I do believe we can find a way forward because ultimately there is broad agreement that Obamacare is not a perfect law and that it has serious issues. I will continue working on a plan to solve our health care woes.

Congress recently passed a bill to fund the Veterans Choice Program, but reform to improve care is still needed. The Veterans Choice Program has the potential to be an important resource for vets to get care closer to home, but only if the program works as it was intended. I continue to hear from veterans and medical providers having problems, including millions of outstanding payments owed to providers. We can and should do better to improve this program for our veterans.

Partisanship and fighting are front and center in Washington D.C. Conflict captures people’s attention and that is what the media reports. I would like to report something you may not realize, but hopefully can also appreciate. Last night the Senate passed more than a dozen legislative actions in a bipartisan fashion. This includes legislation that would fund the Veterans Choice Program, legislation that would streamline the lengthy Veterans Affairs disability claims appeal process, and legislation which calls on the FBI to develop standards and guidelines for the use of automated DNA analysis equipment. This is in addition to approving a new director for the FBI, a circuit court judge and other appointments and resolutions.

Today the Department of the Interior decided to repeal the Obama Administration’s coal, oil and gas valuation rule that would have stifled energy development. I appreciate that the Trump Administration is continuing to rollback these harmful regulations that should have never been proposed in the first place. Our energy sectors should be encouraged to invest in the future for our communities and our country, not discouraged and punished for their efforts to create affordable energy.
Don’t get scammed. Know how the IRS contacts taxpayers and remember to always ask for credentials.

It was great to participate in the 25th Annual Wyoming Congressional Awards Golf Invitational with Senator John Barrasso the last few days in Jackson Hole. Every year, the Wyoming delegation comes together to support the Wyoming Congressional Award. This group of participants has earned their bronze and silver medals and will earn their gold medals in 2018. They represent Rock Springs, Laramie, Lander and Cheyenne. Thanks to Trista Ostrom, director of the Wyoming program, for all her support for this wonderful program. Congressional Awards provide opportunities for young people to achieve personal goals focused on character development, fitness, community involvement and volunteerism. More than 900 young people in Wyoming have earned this award. If you’re interested in learning more, click here: http://bit.ly/2wucpl7

I was saddened to hear about the tragic events in Charlottesville and my prayers are with the victims. White supremacist notions, hate and violence have no place in our society. They run counter to our values that we all share as Americans. We as a nation have come so far, fighting wars at home and abroad, to protect the idea that all individuals are created equal. We should condemn those who use violence to propagate hate, racism or anti-Semitism in our country.

Sent a letter to President Trump with Senator John Barrasso and Rep. Liz Cheney voicing objections to a proposal by Governor Justice of West Virginia to provide a $4.5 billion annual subsidy to eastern coal producers. The proposal would provide a $15-per-ton subsidy to utilities that purchase eastern coal over coal produced in western states, such as Wyoming. As the coal industry recovers from eight years of attacks from the Obama Administration, the federal government should not be picking winners and losers in the marketplace or creating benefits for certain regions over others. The best way to help coal miners throughout the country is by continuing the regulatory relief the Trump Administration has already provided that will allow American coal to compete in a free market.

It’s been wonderful to travel around Wyoming the last couple weeks. Yesterday I spent the day in Casper attending the Petroleum Association of Wyoming Annual Meeting & Trade Show, a luncheon with the Casper Area Chamber of Commerce and an open house reception hosted by the Community Health Centers of Central Wyoming to honor the 5th anniversary in their building. Then I headed to Douglas for the Wyoming Livestock Roundup Ag Picnic. To top it off, Senator John Barrasso and I held a tele-town hall to speak with folks across the state.

The solar eclipse is just around the corner, and Wyoming is on track to be one of the best places to see this once-in-a-lifetime experience. In the last two weeks, I have traveled to many of the towns that will be in the path of the eclipse and the excitement and preparation is remarkable. I am told we might see the population of the state double from all the visitors. But make sure you are prepared and ensure you have the proper glasses to view the eclipse safely.

It was great to celebrate the dedication of the veteran’s memorial in Dubois last weekend with Rep. Liz Cheney. We owe so much to those who have sacrificed for our country, and this memorial stands as a reminder of that. Afterward, I attended the annual Dubois Buffalo BBQ and spoke with folks around the area.

Diana and I had a wonderful time at the Wyoming State Fair parade in Douglas on Saturday. After that, Senator John Barrasso, Representative Liz Cheney, Governor Matt Mead and I presented families with the Centennial Farm and Ranch Award for owning and operating the same land in Wyoming for more than 100 years. To date, 266 families have been honored. Thanks to Wyoming State Historic Preservation Office for re-establishing this great program.

Thank you to Wyoming’s first responders for helping people affected by Hurricane Harvey in Texas. My thoughts and prayers are with everyone impacted. For those interested, this article includes resources for how you can help.

It was a pleasure to tour Cheyenne’s new playground at Cahill Park last weekend. This playground’s theme is Wyoming Exploration of Travel and was created for children with all abilities. Funds were raised from grants and private donations from local groups including the Women’s Civic League, Lions Club, Kiwanis, Rotary, Optimists, Laramie County Library, the Friendship Playground Fund and local businesses. I am proud to see the community come together and contribute to a great cause.
It was nice to visit the Sheridan Senior Center on Monday. I enjoyed meeting with residents over lunch. Thanks to the staff for giving me a tour of the center.

In order to counteract the huge increases in health insurance costs that are a result of Obamacare, we need to find ways to change another unfortunate result of the health care law - a lack of affordable choice. Today the Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee (HELP) Chairman Lamar Alexander, R-Tenn., and Ranking member Patty Murray, D-Wash., held the first of four hearings on stabilizing the market and making health care more affordable. Wyoming and Oklahoma both only have one insurer left in the individual market. I appreciated some of the suggestions for increasing choice offered by Oklahoma Insurance Commissioner John Doak, especially allowing small businesses to pool together to offer their employees better, more affordable, health insurance. More to come.

September 11, 2001 was a day our country will never forget. The memory of the Americans who lost their lives remains. We also continue to remember the sacrifices and selflessness of the firefighters, doctors, emergency medical technicians, police, military personnel and other first responders. Despite being a nation of individuals with our own stories, our own ambitions and our own plans for our lives, today we come together as one in remembrance. We are united in our belief that no one should have to endure a tragedy as terrible as the events that unfolded 16 years ago today.

Congress continues to push to improve America’s health care system. Waivers from Affordable Care Act (ACA) requirements could provide health care flexibility, but governors say the process takes too long. On Thursday at a Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (HELP) Committee hearing, governors spoke about the importance of respecting the regional differences and demands in the marketplace for health care coverage. One of the ways that could help would be to make ACA “1332 waivers” more accessible by cutting down on bureaucracy. Learn more here: http://bit.ly/2wTqdJ9

After learning that the IRS rehired former employees that had been fired, Senator Burr and I are calling on Congress to stop the federal agency from rehiring personnel unless it considers their misconduct. Common sense would suggest that an employee who was fired for misconduct or poor performance shouldn’t be hired back, but the IRS’s outrageous and bewildering behavior defies logic. Instead of following reason, the IRS continues to confuse the stick with the carrot, rewarding their employees’ bad behavior with favorable outcomes.

In a continuing effort to improve America’s health care system, I introduced legislation today that would allow small businesses to work together to provide better health care for their employees. I have heard from small businesses for years regarding the need for greater flexibility and more options for providing health insurance coverage to their employees. The Small Business Health Plans bill would allow small businesses to work together to have greater negotiating power for better prices and greater benefits for their employees.

It also calls for aircraft modernization and supports a helicopter replacement program. The world is a dangerous place and it is important that we as a nation are prepared.

America’s tax system is a complicated mess that is slowing our economy and hurting American families, plain and simple. Congress has the opportunity to right the ship by passing real tax reform that will make our tax code simpler and fairer for all Americans. We can help jumpstart our economy by providing pro-growth tax relief that will put more money in the hands of hard-working families across the country. This would mean more jobs. More jobs lead to competition to get workers and that drives up wages. Tax relief helps grow the economy because Americans, not the federal government, know best how to spend their hard-earned money.

I introduced bipartisan legislation today with Senator Michael Bennet, D-Colo., to make permanent the successful Voluntary Protection Program, a proven workplace health and safety program. It already protects the health and safety of employees while saving the government and private sector hundreds of millions of dollars by avoiding injuries and illness. It is time we cement this program into law to ensure that it can grow and provide help for more of America’s small businesses.

Tax reform is about letting people keep more of what they earn to help grow the economy. That’s why the Senate’s latest tax reform proposal repeals the Obamacare individual mandate that fines people who can’t afford to buy health insurance. Congress is one step closer to passing concrete reforms to the broken U.S. tax code as the full Senate took up consideration of tax reform legislation earlier today. This bill would help grow the economy, create jobs and ensure that Americans are not missing available tax relief. If we followed the budget we passed earlier this year, we could offset tax cuts by relying on economic growth and sensible fiscal restraint. If the economy reached 3.2% growth on average under the new tax plan, part of the debt would be paid down from the extra revenue generated. This tax plan is an investment in hardworking Americans – one that will produce a stronger and more competitive American economy.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau was born of politics and is shielded from accountability to the public. We need to change that. I was pleased to join Senator Sasse and others in making this clear. Click below to learn more.

The need for Congress to bring accountability to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is long overdue and the bureau’s lavish spending on employee salaries is a key example of why. I introduced a bill with Congressman Sean Duffy, R-Wis., that would ensure the bureau is keeping employees’ salaries in line with the regular government pay scale. There are hundreds of employees at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau making more than governors, Supreme Court justices and senior White House staff, and Congress lacks the usual constitutional checks to rein in this behavior. Hopefully this bill will be the start of many needed reforms.

In rural and other medically under-served communities, physician assistants may be the only health care professional available for hospice care. But under current Medicare law, they are not allowed to serve as hospice attending physicians. I introduced bipartisan legislation with Senator Tom Carper to allow physician assistants to provide and manage hospice care for Medicare beneficiaries. Patients in need of hospice care should not have to worry that they will be unable to receive quality care because of unnecessary regulations.

The Senate just passed historic tax reform legislation to help hardworking Americans. I am confident that under this bill, people can expect to see more money in their pockets and a stronger economy. It would cut tax rates across the board, nearly double the standard deduction, double the child-tax credit, essentially eliminate Obamacare’s individual mandate and more. These savings would result in a typical American family of four, earning the median family income of $73,000, seeing their taxes drop by more than $2,000. The bill would also provide tax relief for small and large businesses to help them invest in our communities to grow the economy. It also provides meaningful international tax reform to incentives companies to keep jobs at home, while allowing them to compete overseas. The legislation is truly about making a better future for folks in Wyoming and across the country.
